comment.author: 33472394@N00
comment._content: I think this is looking down Washington Street near the intersection with Water Street.

comment.author: 35740357@N03
comment._content: Thanks for the modern day view, Eric in SF! Did you know the National Archives is currently running a contest for photos that mash-up the old and new images? Check out our challenge and look at some of the photos already submitted in our Flickr group. Hope to see your submissions soon! Mary U.S. National Archives

comment.author: 39312862@N00
comment._content: Very cool. I don't live in NYC so it'll be a bit hard for me to participate in this particular contest, unless I'm not understanding it correctly. But the entries in the group pool were way cool!

comment.author: 35740357@N03
comment._content: We welcome all creative interpretations of the old and the new together, and any photo from our collections is eligible for the contest. One of the suggestions in our History Happens Here set could be perfect for where you are now! Mary U.S. National Archives

comment.author: 82333187@N00
comment._content: Congratulations, your photo has been nominated for the Photo of the Week contest by the Time & Place group. Please nominate your candidate for the current contest. (Or you can second a photo that's already been nominated.) Thank you for playing!

comment._content:

comment.author: 27217430@N02
comment._content: Wow, looks a little different these days.

comment.author: 12458821@N08
comment._content:
I was going to comment on the average age of cars in this pic being two or three years and that of the modern one around 10 years, but then I saw [http://www.flickr.com/photos/ericinsf]'s picture was taken in 2005.
Point stands - for as otherwise-desolate as the 1974 pic is, there are no old beaters and some pretty nice cars in it. Maybe that has to do with the proclivity of '60s/70s cars to rust and the high fixed costs of car ownership in NYC.
